Chryseobacterium terrae is considered a soil bacterium, as it was originally isolated from soil samples. It is capable of growing at temperatures ranging from 15°C to 37°C, with an optimal growth temperature of around 28°C.

This species is characterized by its ability to produce yellow-pigmented colonies on agar media due to the production of carotenoid pigments. It is also known to be capable of hydrolyzing various substrates, such as starch, casein, and Tween 80.
